awd_titl_txt: CAREER: "Holey Scaffold" Sensing System for Characterization of the Spatiotemporal Tumor Response to Nanoparticle-Mediated Photothermal and Photochemical Therapy
awd_abstract_narration:
0955072
Rylander

The goal of this CAREER plan is to create and utilize a novel sensing system called the "holey scaffold" to nondestructively and minimally invasively measure dynamic nanoparticle transport and photothermal and photochemical tumor response to nanoparticle-mediated laser therapy. A holey scaffold is a new technology co-invented by the PI that is composed of an embedded network of microchannels within a scaffold framework upon which cells and tissues can be grown. Hollow core fibers integrated in the holey scaffold permit simultaneous optical sensing/imaging of dynamic processes and selective delivery of biological agents (e.g. nutrients, cells, nanoparticles) for control of biochemical responses. The CAREER objective is to use holey scaffolds to measure 1) spatiotemporal nanoparticle transport for varying nanoparticle properties, targeting approaches, and delivery methods, 2) dynamic photothermal response (temperature, heat shock protein expression, and cell injury), and 3) real-time photochemical response (reactive oxygen species production) associated with nanoparticle-mediated laser therapies. The versatility of holey scaffolds will enable the first measurement of dynamic tumor response in vitro within a bioreactor system and in vivo in a mouse tumor model. Measured tumor response will be utilized to create a novel computational model for predicting tumor response and optimizing implementation of nanoparticles in laser therapy.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: By integrating tissue-engineering strategies with cancer biology, microscale fluid mechanics, and optical flow diagnostics, we created a novel sensing platform for minimally invasive and non-destructive measurement and control of dynamic biological and transport processes. This system was used to effectively characterize the spatiotemporal nanoparticle transport and dynamic photothermal/photochemical response to nanoparticle-mediated therapy for varying nanoparticle properties and laser parameters within an in vivo tumor systems. The novel sensing platform and predictive computational models developed provided a unique repertoire of enabling technologies to characterize dynamic nanoparticle diffusion and tissue response to nanoparticle-mediated laser therapies. Tissue response to novel nanoparticles including carbon nanohorns, endohedral metallofullerenes, and peapod nanostructures were investigated. Knowledge of the photothermal and photochemical tumor response assisted in the design of more effective nanoparticle-mediated laser therapies by allowing determination of ideal nanoparticle and laser parameters, refinement of nanoparticle delivery and targeting methods, and identification of appropriate timing between nanoparticle introduction and laser irradiation. Ultimately, the transformative understanding of tumor response gained from this research will enable achievement of my long-term career goal of developing effective nanotechnology-based therapies for many medical applications including the treatment of cancer, cardiovascular disease, and neuromuscular dysfunction.

Broader Impacts: This CAREER plan established a multi-tier education and outreach plan that integrated research elements and discoveries into multidisciplinary educational and research experiences for high school students and teachers, undergraduates, and graduate students. The program reenergized the classroom experience by implementing a paradigm shifting educational approach focused on research-inspired learning and provided research opportunities to captivate excitement in engineering. Problem based exercises and interactive demonstrations were developed for high school, undergraduate, and graduate courses based on CAREER research discoveries and core technologies. The CAREER research provided the foundation for mini-projects at the high school and undergraduate level to dissertations at the graduate level. This program served as a synergistic vehicle for personal growth of all participants by stimulating excellence in leadership, mentoring, teaching, learning, and research. The capability of our novel sensing platform to measure and control dynamic processes in real-time provided enormous insight necessary for optimizing cancer therapy and tissue regeneration. This study supplied critical understanding to advance nanotherapeutics development closer to clinical implementation as a more selective, effective, and minimally invasive cancer treatment alternative to surgical resection, chemotherapy, and radiation. Integration of these therapies into mainstream medicine will have enormous socioeconomic benefits and dramatically enhance the quality and length of life for millions of patients suffering from cancer and other diseases. 

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2022
Modified by: Marissa N Rylander
